results.title: Food and people
results.brief_description: Draws a contrast between people who have plenty to eat and those who have next to nothing. Followers of Thomas Malthus are convinced that a world of plenty will never be possible; others believe the world’s population should be limited; and another group advocates the increase of food production and distribution. The latter concept also stresses conservation of resources and improved agricultural methods. Emphasises that with free world trade, peoples of all nations will benefit. Suggests that a world of plenty provides greater chances for individual security and world peace.

results.title: Food and growth
results.brief_description: Explains the functions of the mouth, stomach and intestine in the digestion of food. Shows how food is carried by the circulatory system to the cells, allowing cell division and growth. Suitable for upper primary and lower and middle secondary levels.

results.title: Food additives
results.creator_credit: Open Tafe, Box Hill College of Technical and Further Education, Deborah Manners and Shane Mulcahy
results.brief_description: A discussion with Dr. K. Farrer, author of “Fancy eating that” who describes the history of food additives and examines what is added and why. He also addresses the safety aspects of additives and regulations to control their use. Hosted by Peter Couchman.

results.title: Food (for) thought
results.creator_credit: Victorian College of the Arts, Dennis Tupicoff and Daniel Crooks
results.brief_description: Food. Religion. Television. Using a multiplicity of styles, this technically accomplished animation seeks to present a critique of religion and consumer culture. It makes an impressive idiosyncratic statement, with stylistic references to Jan Svankmajer and the Brothers Quay.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Victorian College of the Arts, Dennis Tupicoff and Daniel Crooks

results.title: Food
results.brief_description: An animated film, without commentary, produced by a guest filmmaker from India, Gopal K. Gokhale, during a period of workstudy at the National Film Board. The film is intended to demonstrate to farm audiences in developing countries how improved farming practices and technology increase crop yield and income. Film without words.
